instruction: What time of day is ideal for getting things done like that?
output: All right, pick your time of day. So it's really worth noting the time of day you're most productive. And it differs for different people. Oftentimes it's in the morning, oftentimes this can be chosen in conjunction with your medication. So I would know, for example, when I take Dextroenthetamine that I eat after half an hour because if I ate before I took it, then it would mess up the absorption. After an hour it kicks in and then I'm not hungry anymore. So that's the perfect timing. After about an hour and a half to 2 hours, I will have the maximum effect for say, an hour and a half. So if I plan something that time, that would be ideal. But the next thing is the hard thing for us isn't necessarily the most complicated thing and sometimes we assume it is. So, if you've got to do I can think of a time when I was having this conversation with a client. So he's a coder and enjoys the innovative coding that he has to do, but he's coming up with it as he goes. But there's a whole bunch of stuff that he's just got to fill in. Details that are repetitive but can't be copied and pasted. And that's where he would tend to it. Like, that first task that's actually more complicated, right? And a lot of people will intuitively choose to put the more complicated stuff during the time that they're most focused on their best. But actually, for people with ADHD, it's often the other way around, where in the late afternoon, where there's probably no chance that you would do admin work and stuff like that. You should wait till 05:00 come so you can leave. During that time, you might actually be able to inspire yourself to do the exciting stuff, even though it's more complicated and potentially focused. Fine. While during the time that you're best focused, that's actually for those mundanities we were talking about, it's the most difficult thing to motivate yourself to do at that moment, which is generally not the most complicated thing. It's generally what's often the simplest, but it's also often the most work for the most minor overall outcome-based utility. Be aware of attentional traps like Facebook and YouTube and everything like that.

output: I see where you're going. I've got two suggestions that I think would be a good start. So one, just because the morning is a part where we can absolutely have control, in a sense, when people. It is difficult to kind of pull themselves out of bed at that time. One way to do it is to turn off snooze on your phone and set your alarm somewhere where you can't physically reach you from the bed so that you are forced to get up to turn it off, where it's just going to keep on going, going because the snooze isn't there. Sometimes people are like, well, if they just turn it off and then go back to bed, which often just works anyway. But if they find that they go back to bed, then another way is, like, they might put the clothes on that they want to throw on in the morning, like underneath their phone, so that they pick up their phone and their clothes are right there ready to go. Another way is like so waking up in the morning and getting rid of that kind of melatonin so that you're not feeling sleepy like you go back to sleep again. That only takes being physically active to the point of walking fast with intent to the bathroom and going to the bathroom and walking fast back, as opposed to stumbling into the bathroom as we might do in the middle of the night. That act of intentional coordination will wake us up in some way, like hyperventilating, is another one where people really find it difficult to get out of bed, particularly in the winter. They can, like, literally just like, sit up in bed or even lay down in bed if you hyperventilate, like, really for like 20 seconds, guarantee you won't want to go back to sleep. So there are different ways to kind of hack it like that. Another way would be like, once you've, like, you know, you've gotten up to grab your phone, you might be like, well, I'm not willing to, like, fully decided to get up. But it's like, well, am I willing to fully decide to just go to the bathroom and then I'll decide whether I go back to bed or do the other thing? The more little things that we have in between, the less likely we're going to want to go back to sleep. So that's the morning side, and there are just techniques around there. And then I'd suggest at night time just having a novelty cut off so you don't have to worry so much about, am I asleep yet? Am I asleep? That's something that this is going to contribute to. But you don't have to be checking in so quickly because it's just like, you have that novelty cut off. I would suggest half an hour before the time at which you want to get to sleep, so about the time at which you want to go to bed. So about 10:00 p.m. And that just means, like if you watch TV or read a book or listen to an audiobook or anything like that, that you would do it with something that you've already read or seen or whatever. So that in a sense, sleepiness comes in waves. So there's this tiredness or fatigue that occurs depending on what we do throughout the day. But we can be tired and not get sleepy to the point that we can sleep. That sense that you're like, yeah, I could go to sleep at this moment that comes in waves. So if we are, say, watching something that we want to finish, or we're reading a book, and we want to know what happens at the end of the chapter, if we, like, get sleepy and then we finish that section, we're likely not to be sleepy by the time the next section is finished. So then we've got to wait for the next wave in a sense, which is about 30 minutes to 60 minutes, depending on the person and how tired they are, the period of these. So the novelty cut-off is primarily so you've got something you're willing to stop at any time, right? So no matter what that is, that's the primary thing. So just cutting off the novelty and working in the morning will make it so much easier to make this shift in the future without taking on every single island.

instruction: Alex one of the things that I find really tricky about working out what to do and what not to do is I find it really hard to imagine how long something is going to take. But like this time blind, at some point in a week maybe someone will be like jonah, are you able to give a talk to the year eleven, explain how I know something really kind of specific and complex about the ground? Romanticism? I'm like, yeah, sure, sounds good. I'll make a thorough PowerPoint. output: I know what you mean. I've blocked that, that's fine. So yeah, so time blindness, the lack of a sense of how long things are going to take. But I want to make the distinction between trance or the experience of time at the moment versus our ability to potentially learn how long things take retrospectively or looking forward. So people with the awareness of time, the awareness of the flow of time and how long things take, very much is determined by checking in and having that sense of like, well, I've checked in at this time. There's some sense that roughly a certain amount of time has passed and then I check in again, that kind of thing. So that requires having some degree of your attention left over to do that kind of checking in. When people with ADHD are really intently hyper-focusing, they're not going to do as much of that kind of checking in because they're going to be fully immersed and at that time they experience what we call trance, where we feel like something takes less time than it did. So that's the experience in the moment and that's part of what leads to this sense of time blindness. But another big part of it is also like that it's the lack of planning. And it's worth noting that this kind of sense of how long is a certain task going to take? This is not beyond people with ADHD. It just means being intentional about it. Right. Because there is that time blindness just looking back in your memory and being like, how long did that task feel like it took? That's likely to be inaccurate, but if you actually note, alright, so I think X task is going to take me so long like you estimate what it is going to take you 2 hours and then, you know, I saw it this time, then it took me this long. And we repetitively get that information even if we're not deliberately noting it down in a way that we can come back to that experience over time will calibrate our sense of how long things are going to take. But it does mean intentionally kind of doing that. But noteworthy, it's not something that like by doing these things that you've got to do in order to take advantage of it anyway, you would be enacting that process that would improve your ability to determine how long things will take.

instruction: Tell me about the link between relationships and mood.
output: Well, we feel happy when we're around friends and loved ones. Good relationships make us more resilient to depression. They increase connectedness and general mood. And isolation, on the other hand, leads to lethargy and low mood over time in general, and oftentimes, it can be a slow burn. I certainly noticed that over the course of lockdown where even for myself, I remember thinking after I've been in lockdown for a couple of months, I was like, yeah, you know, things are fine. Like it had been a slow enough burn that I didn't really realise that I was feeling a bit less kind of energetic or into things than I was. And then I went and had a great weekend with friends and stuff like that. We just got out of lockdown for the weekend or whatever, and the amount that I was uplifted that I felt better made it very clear that, slowly and gradually, I had lost a bit of enthusiasm for things just through isolation. And I noticed that this was true for many clients I had over that time, particularly those who may feel a bit of social anxiety or whatever. So there's some sort of propensity to be like, well, that's a bit stressful, I don't have to do that, I won't socialise. But it can still lead to a bit of like you just feel less in, less in life, less in with other people, I guess, in the meantime. So I think that picture pretty much says it all. It's not necessarily a physical activity, you could have time that is that, but it could be a place that you enjoy being.

instruction: Attention things. Attention-heavy tasks. Hobbies yes.
output: So to do tasks that require a lot of self-control yes. Placing your attention on things that you don't really want to place your attention on, that if we're doing that and we know we've got to do that to do whatever task at hand, then it's also important to make sure we have low attention rests in between. Like, say, going for a walk, just letting our thoughts wander, maybe even going outside and just kind of seeing in a place where you enjoy the atmosphere. Because you imagine, like, if you're doing something physical day, like building a fence and then you go to the gym in your lunch break, that wouldn't be a very good idea in terms of being as efficient as you can to do that physical tasks. And that's often what we do, where we jump between trying to focus on something mundane or whatever it is, some admin task and then potentially jump to maybe video games or something like that, where there is actually a high degree of attention that you're paying, and that may not be a very good rest. So that you can actually come back effectively and efficiently and do the thing at hand. And also just noting that we don't relax and rest very well when we kind of like force ourselves to stay in a room like that, where it's like a self-punishment thing, I must do something where I won't leave. It's a good idea, if you're not being productive, to get up every half an hour and go for a bit of a walk at the blood flow and things like that. We're stepping away from that kind of self-punishment aspect. So deciding what to and what not to take on, all the most important things you already have to do, you consider what those are at any moment. And it can be a very good idea to actually do this practice where you think of a week coming up, say, for work. That might be something you do, like on a Sunday or something like that, whatever day kind of fits to then look at the next seven days and to think, what are the tasks that I've got to do over that time? Whether it be work, university life, admin, or everything like that. And you get a sense of how busy you are in terms of how much your time is actually taken up. Noting that you've got to spend some of that time actually having a bit of fun and doing things like balancing out that lifestyle. It's really important to do because once you do if you get asked then to do something for someone or maybe even to meet some friends or something like that, something that's either more exciting than the thing that you've got to do. So it's really tempting to try to justify it. Or there's a sense of like, somebody needs your help, and you want to help them. It's novel, it's more interesting. There are all these factors that can make that a more appealing thing. So we want to increase the certainty that it's a bad idea if it is a bad idea. And if you know that your week is pretty much full and adding another thing is going to mean that either you're going to be flustered beyond your resources or you're going to have to let something slide, then it becomes a lot easier to say no right at that moment. It's when we can't justify that to ourselves. So it's like, why wouldn't I say no? And often that's exactly what our brain is going to like default to if we want to change from the thing that we're doing and the more that we want to change, the more aversive it is, and the more we're going to be like, the more our brain is going to convince us to do something else.

output: During our meeting, I shared my personal struggle finding a psychiatrist when I moved from Sydney to Melbourne. Following that, we began our introductory session on understanding ADHD over the course of our future sessions. In week one, we'll demystify ADHD, looking into what it means and its overall implications. For week two, we'll dive into specific techniques to command attention, focusing on adrenalising and leveraging norepinephrine, a neurotransmitter that's under-regulated for ADHD. Adrenalising can help improve focus, especially when there's a sense of high stakes, accountability, or the presence of others. The next strategy for focus involves genuine interest. I shared my own experience where I was deeply intrigued by ADHD due to my diagnosis, but when asked to prepare this course, my interest had shifted elsewhere. To draw my attention back to ADHD, I rekindled my excitement and curiosity about the subject, rather than forcing myself into it, a prime example of trying differently. Our next sessions will focus on goal setting, including techniques to avoid overcommitment due to people-pleasing tendencies. After that, we'll move to improving your baseline lifestyle, with considerations for diet, sleep, and practices like mindfulness meditation. This will be followed by deeper exploration of traumas, emotional issues, and core beliefs affecting those with ADHD. Then, we'll define ADHD and discuss its traits. We'll look into its impact on focus, hyperfocus conditions, issues like drifting off during conversations, and how ADHD brains differ from average ones in developmental stages, neurochemistry, and neuromechanics. Lastly, I introduced the Pomodoro technique, which employs an egg timer (or a "pomodoro" - Italian for tomato) to break up tasks and manage focus. This tool uses classical conditioning, similar to Pavlov's experiments, to create associations that help ramp up focus through adrenalizing. I hope this gives everyone a comprehensive overview of what our sessions will entail. Do we have any questions so far?

instruction: But it feels like pushing uphill. How does it get easier?
output: It's getting those small wins. Especially people have been in situations where they have like they've put in effort for whatever it is they've tried hard, and they have felt helpless that their efforts haven't gotten anywhere. Like, for example, when people have been in a workplace that's quite toxic, and perhaps if it is bullying and stuff like that, people can really feel helpless in that environment because it doesn't matter how hard they try to do their work well. It doesn't matter what they do. Often times they will always, you know, get that bad feedback if the person, you know, their manager or whoever it is, is really just trying to make them uncomfortable enough to leave the organisation. I've certainly worked with people who have been through that. And it really is like the best thing we can do is build up small wins, small goals so that they can start to prove to themselves again that they are capable. Because it can very much not feel like that after a while. After a year, two years, or three years of being in an organisation where you feel very sidelined and bullied.

instruction: How can I hack tasks to keep me engaged?
output: Hone excellent method is by setting up "environmental anchors". All of our minds wander without us realising on a conscious level and we look to the environment for cues as to what we're doing before consciously learning it. This isn't just people with ADHD, of course, and so this happens in the background while we're doing a task what am I doing again? And at that moment we don't even know that it's happening and we either get pulled into something else based on like oh, that's what I'm doing, and then kind of jump into that and that might be half an hour later before you consciously realize and then pull yourself back. But you can set up choose in the environment that are associated with doing particular things. Like I was talking about with classical conditioning last time with the Pavlovian dog who salivates at the sound of a gong and using the Pomodoro technique with the egg timer so that you've got the auditory ticking anchor or some YouTube thing that has a Pomodoro thing that does a similar something and have the visual marker of the tomato timer on the table and stuff. These are the type of visual anchors and it's worth noting that there are plenty of situations where there are naturally visual anchors if you're digging a hole like they are, like they're wearing gloves, they're standing over a hole with other people holding a shovel. When that moment happens, it's like what am I doing again? Very clearly you know what you're doing. That you're actually doing something else that pulls you in. So we're limiting that by removing those distractions and maximizing the ones that are associated with what we want it to be other people. So of course they provide an anchor to the task as well. If you're sitting around studying with people and you can see what they're doing, what you're doing, this provides a thematic anchor of like yeah, we're studying this subject as well.

Like the significant thing that happens in a lot of ways is that you normalize to hyper normal stimuli. So like you think of the amount of novelty you have in the world with the people you see or attractiveness or whatever it is, whatever it is that we're kind of we're looking for out in the world, the amount that we see all at once, all quickly, it's so much greater than the actual thing could be. You think of like a classic example is there's sex where you have to be, you know, you have to find some book but then there's pornography, right? The novelty, the access and all that kind of stuff. Once you get habituated to that, they will often lose their interest for sex. They lose their interest—that drive for many things. And in the same vein with social networking and stuff, people will often find that. I've had people primarily come to me in what they describe before we realize that the issue is like scrolling their social media too much is that they're like, you know, sometimes I just feel like bored, but like I should be doing something but there's nothing I want to do, nothing's interesting. That's the feeling that people get when they don't allow themselves to actually be bored because they're constantly filling that with something. Like the way that I put it is that the feeling of boredom is like the feeling of hunger where it's not pleasant, but it's also essential. After you haven't eaten for a while, you feel hungry and that'll make you go out and seek some food that you need some nutrients. But you can get rid of that hunger signal by eating white bread and margarine. And that'll keep you going for a while as you're getting depleted of everything else, but it's not going to keep you going very well. Right? And to me, like just constantly filling every moment we have with something just because we can't stand not having anything, it's just white bread and margarine. It takes away our drive to actually go out and seek something interesting. And when I get people to actually just pull back to the extent that they've got a bit of time where they're just allowing their mind to wonder that they feel more inspired, they feel more creative, they're more likely to spontaneously have ideas that they're interested in pursuing. And there's even research showing that people's creativity improves to the point that they actually even perform better. When it comes to a lateral thinking based task, one example would be like, here's a paper cup. How many things can you think of in two minutes to do with it? So it's like innovatively thinking of ways that you can utilize something. This is the lateral thinking task. People do better at that task when they've allowed themselves to be bored. They do worse when they're constantly filling up all their stimulus.

instruction: Explain more about the relative strengths people with ADHD have academically.
output: Generally speaking, more so than not, people with ADHD are better with the exam side of things, where the pressure is on, but the assignments and the readings consistently over time, not so much—and perhaps studying more toward the end rather than consistently approaching it all throughout the session, unless you've got a rigorous plan to do so. Because at that time, that's when you're adrenalized, that's when you have access to Norepinephrine. And creating that last-minute effect can be done by, like, setting up, say, if you've got a friend you do an edit for every now and then. They do an edit of something you've written every now and then, setting up a time and saying, all right, can I send you my paper tomorrow? So then you've got an idea, like you want to do as much as you can so it's as helpful as possible before you actually send it to them. Or if you were doing a PhD and you had a supervisor to set up a nonnegotiable deadline that you see in a certain amount so you could decide and set a date with your supervisor if that was a situation. For example, to actually have dates where you have the intro, the method, the conclusion, that kind of thing, you're piecemealing it a bit so you don't just get such a massive unsupervised set of work. So non negotiable deadlines, pomodoro and getting revved up. And also it's worth noting that exercise I may have mentioned in the past, about 30 minutes of high intensive cardio exercise, leads to a two hour window in which people with ADHD have up regulated their Norepinephrine endopley into such a degree that it doesn't actually differ, all else being equal to the average person. So, very, very handy to do exercise in the morning before you want to get going and focus. And what I've found as well, particularly because sleep is often an issue for people with ADHD, is that more exercise than the average person is required to get the most out of it. Like most people, they can get good sleep and stuff like that with, say, this amount of exercise. But doing more for people with ADHD still continues to have a positive effect in my experience, and a really beneficial one in terms of being less inclined to do those, to get in that mode where you feel bored, where you feel like nothing's really that interesting, to lose momentum with things. And also, particularly if it's in the morning, like I said, the ability to adrenalize and feel good about accomplishments throughout the day to some degree.

Another is because the prefrontal cortex of people with ADHD, although it catches up in almost every aspect, by the time people with ADHD are adults, there is a delay in the development of the prefrontal cortex that can be really present around mid to late primary school and potentially lead to bullying. Because there's a one to two-year difference in the ability to understand social nuance. So that can lead to some bullying as well. That can lead to a sense of rejection, which then could be then taken care of by a person in a similar way of the unrelenting standards of people pleading. instruction: Can you guide me not to be so hard on myself when I don't achieve my goals?
output: So it's really important to draw our attention to the accomplishments that we have had, even quite deliberately, so that we can make up for that in some way. We'll talk about reviewing reasons why you might not have been perfect with your goals because it's not about being impractical or about pretending that you have done better than we have. It's just simply being fair to ourselves and being realistic about how much has been accomplished so that we have a point to move from. As soon as we kind of jump into beating ourselves up about what we haven't done and whatnot, actually, it stops us from jumping in and thinking about the logical reasons for which we might not have done it. Because we kind of get caught into that negative thought pattern of like, this is my fault, blah blah blah. This is incongruent with thinking about that fair idea of the different things that might have come up that may not come up in the future, that could be changed around and everything like that. And oftentimes, we jump to the assumption that if we haven't completed our goal that it's due to some lack of performance, but oftentimes it is a lack of kind of sorting out some aspect of the organisation of it so that we've got the reminders, we've got the time and everything like that. Because we can so easily just need to refine it a little bit the next time, but we're not going to be able to see the woods through the trees kind of and be able to see how we can shape it up going into the future. And also to not have an aversive experience, right? To have a nice positive experience through having the goals. Because it leads to betterment rather than being like, well, I thought I was going to fail and then, to my perception, I did. It's all about kind of reshaping that a bit. We'll talk about how to deal with a whole bunch of goals that you have in life, as most of us do have many things, perhaps at any given time that we would like to change or we would like to do differently or better. But it is really important to note that if we try to do all of these things at once, then we're just trying to do too many novel things that we've got to directly pay attention to build up as new habits all at once and we're doubtful to be able to do that. I frame it up as trying to learn to ride a bike at the same time as learning to ride without no hands. It's like, well, let's learn how to ride first, get the feeling of the balance and then we can throw in something extra once. A lot of it is quite routine because you think about somebody when they're doing something like that. They're learning how to ride a bike. Or you think about when you have learnt something that you don't have muscle memory for and the amount of little things you've got to think about consciously. Like, I've got to, like while I kind of push down here, I've got to be leaning this way and like all the little things that absolutely require no attention down the track. And I mean, because of that, we're very limited in the amount of extra stuff we can take on, especially once you factor in lifestyle and everything else you've got to do. So these are like potentially new things that you're stacking on top of potentially an abundance of other things that you do all the time, and then we're creating a situation that is very likely to lead to what we perceive as a failure and therefore give us the sense that we're not able to achieve consistency over time. And like I mentioned in the past, particularly in my experience working with people with ADHD, and it's been something true for myself as well, that sometimes the most important thing to do first is just to have any small goal that you can do consistently, patiently, over the course of weeks to prove to yourself that something can be completely under your control in terms of the time that you do it, the way that you do it, and everything like that. So there isn't that sense that when you're focused, your output is dictated by spontaneous bouts of motivation rather than your control over it. And that's not to say that we want to have that direct decidedness for everything we do; it's just that it's possible. So therefore, when things really matter, then we do it for that but then it's also the recognition that we don't have enough time, we don't have enough resources to do that for everything, no one does. So then it's that kind of bargaining of, " okay, I'll apply it here, and you're divvying up your resources. You have a certain amount of eggs, and you've got a bunch of baskets and are figuring out which ones to fill up a bit. This is your time, your effort, your energy in the course of a day and everything like that, to place it into those baskets, those areas, the goals in this case that are most important to you. At the time or that is going to build up and give you that sense of accomplishment that will ultimately lead to a better situation down the line in the way that you particularly value rebuilding routines when life happens and they just fall apart. I don't think any, well, no conversation about reviewing goals and everything like that would be complete without just recognising that these goals are made in the context of all the other things that we're doing in life. Sometimes things get shaken up. Sometimes, no matter how hardened and set a routine is, there will be temporary stages where we cannot enact those for whatever reason. And sometimes we're just going to be under a great deal more stress than others, and that can lead to some or perhaps several of these routines that we may have set up over time to fall apart to some degree, right? Whether that's just a reduction from where you were at or whether that's kind of losing momentum and feeling that way. The thing is that anytime that we've developed a goal at any stage, we can rejig it, and we can reinstate it at a stage in the future much more easily, of course, than the first time. And suppose the idea is that having things fall apart is occasionally a failure. In that case, that definition leads to the majority of people being a failure in that way because that is a normal part of life, and we need to see that as such. Alright, any questions about any of that? Any comments? Anything that you guys wanted to say before we crack forward a little bit? Actually, maybe we could. I'll just see what the next slide is. Yeah, perfect. Perhaps after that next slide, we can talk about people's individual goals, but no questions or quandary queries about any of that stuff. Alright, first short Pomodoro set. So, reviewing goals. This is a curious mind. So I just want you to think about the goals. Actually, we'll do it in this order. Let's actually go through everyone's goals, and then we'll apply them as we go forth. I forgot to do the slides from last time. Should I do that at the end, or should I do that right now?

It's also a really important note to make sure that whatever it is that you're trying to change, that the goal is based on, is completely in your control. So many times, people will come up with goals like, I want to achieve a certain grade, for example, right? And it's like, well, yeah, you can have that in mind as something you would like to do. But the overall mark isn't something that's in our control. There are things that we know are going to make us more likely to get a better mark, like making sure that we've spent the time preparing, making sure that we're perhaps using various methods that are going to help us learn. But there must be specific things that we can enact and be totally certain about whether we've enacted them. So that, say, if the overall thing you care about is to get a better grade, the things you have on there make that more likely. You can still end up getting a better grade. But if you have done all of those things that you've had in mind, like studying or whatever it is, and that hasn't resulted in whatever grade you have in mind, you have still 100% succeeded in that endeavour. And I mean, we know particularly after tweaking like a regime of learning and stuff like that over time, that absolutely will lead to the best situation that we can set up in terms of getting the best grades that we can, rather than beating ourselves up about and getting caught up about how much we actually know and everything like that tends to be much better to just focus on. Have I done this thing? Cool, I've done that thing. Then you can turn up on the day knowing that you've done the requirement that was in place, right? And then the rest is up to faith because instead, we tend to beat ourselves kind of up, or it's very easy for people to get very nervous on those exam days. What if there's something there that I don't know? Whatever it is, we will not increase the likelihood of knowing what is on the exam by getting nervous at that time. It's all about and like; this is easier said than done but focusing on, you know what, I've done those things. This is going to lead me to the best position. Just kind of doing it at that stage. That tends to lead to dropping off those nerves over time. There are other factors, of course. They're making sure that it's measurable, which to me is very much akin to making sure that it's specific so that you know exactly whether it has been done and, again, to what extent it's been done. And this one's really important because if we set up multiple goals all at once, or we set something, or we set up a goal that we already have too many other things on so we don't have the extra time or resources to do that. There are plenty of situations that we can throw ourselves into where on the face of it, we could see that we're probably not going to be able to succeed in that. instruction: I heard someone talk about ADHD Coach, and if this response is quick, can I just ask what exactly is the difference between an ADHD Coach and a therapist that trains somebody with ADHD?

I guess the bulk of the stuff that we talk about, say, in this group, like not necessarily getting into trauma and the deeper sides of things.
